Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,
President of the Johns Hopkins
University, has announced a
grant of $80,000 from the Westinghouse Educational Foundation for the establishment of a

The Westinghouse funds will
Provide support for a full professor over a five-year period.
The formal presentation of the
grant to Johns Hopkins was
Made by B. M. Brown, VicePresident, Baltimore Divisions,
Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
In accepting the gift, Dr.
Eisenhower said, "It is most
gratifying to have Westinghouse,
one of the major industries in
the Baltimore area, provide such
substantial aid to the University. I know of no way in which

officials of the Baltimore Divisions of
Westinghouse
who
helped to make possible this important new professorship at
Johns Hopkins."

Point out that the Department

in the School of Engineering are
enrolled in electrical engineering
and fully 25 per cent of all students in McCoy College, the University's evening division, are
taking programs involving electrical engineering courses. In
addition, the Department carries
on an extensive graduate and
research program.

Comedy is the keynote, "Three
Men On A Horse" is the play and
freshmen are the actors in the
annual Barnstormers' freshman
play to be presented Friday,
October 23, in the barn at 8 p.m.

With the exception of three
female acting recruits and Directors Ed Ross and Dennis Donahue, all participants - both
technical and dramatic-in the
play will be Hopkins freshmen.
The girls will come from Notre
Dame, Union Memorial or (last
choice, it is said) Goucher.
The play deals with a writer
of greeting cards who has the
ability to pick horses with unfailing accuracy. He falls into

the hands of some gamblers who
use his ability to make some easy
money. Will he escape? Will he
be allowed to go back to his
greeting cards?

"The play is very humorous,
but it is funny in that there is
no deep plot," said Donanue.
"It is broad-humored and superficial."
The Barnstormers will produce
two other plays during the year:
"The Rainmaker," the weekend
of December 5, and "My Three
Angels," April 23. Donahue announced that the `Stormers are
trying something new this year
by presenting only comedies and
feel sure that the student body
will approve this choice.

ability to pick horses with unfailing accuracy. He falls into

the hands of some gamblers who
use his ability to make some easy
money. Will he escape? Will he
be allowed to go back to his
greeting cards?

but it is funny in that there is
no deep plot," said Donanue.
